block.p: Philip Morris and Reynolds To Buy Parts of Nabisco The Philip Morris Companies, owner of Kraft Foods, said it had reached an agreement to buy Nabisco Holdings, maker of Oreo cookies and Grey Poupon mustard.

After that sale is completed, Nabisco Group Holdings, which holds an 80.6 percent stake in the Nabisco operating company, said it would accept an offer from its former unit, R.J. Reynolds Tobacco. [Page A1.]

Internet Body Faces Lawsuit The Internet's administrative body, already low on cash and facing heavy criticism from international groups, has been served with what is believed to be its first lawsuit challenging its work. The suit was filed by Afternic, a New York company denied entrance to the lucrative business of registering Internet addresses, or domain names. [C8.]

Deutsche Telekom Ends Talks Deutsche Telekom's Internet arm, T-Online International, has withdrawn from talks to acquire Britain's largest Internet service provider, Freeserve, for about $9 billion. [C2.]

Superhero Needed to Save Comics Comic book publishers from the industry giant Marvel Enterprises on down are fighting to increase sales. The task is becoming increasingly difficult as the number of comic book shops drops and fewer newspaper stands and supermarkets carry the magazines. But publishers are trying new models, including sending a young Spider-Man to therapy. [C11.]

Applying an Old Patent to the Web British Telecommunications, dusting off a 14-year-old patent, is claiming ownership of the linking technology that lets Web users move around the Internet by clicking on text and pictures. The company has begun sending letters to Internet service providers in the United States asking them to pay royalties. Patent specialists say British Telecommunications has a difficult case to prove. But they expect the number of such cases to rise as people try to apply old and new patents to broad areas of the Internet. [C4.]

Madison Ave.'s Don't Ask, Don't Tell Few executives on Madison Avenue have publicly disclosed their homosexuality -- as a stock analyst on Wall Street did last week -- and many in the advertising industry say such a step would still be deemed surprising. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C16.]

Cloning Patent Raises Questions A Wisconsin company has won a patent that it says overcomes a critical obstacle in cloning mammal cells. The company, Infigen, owns a large herd of cloned cattle which produce genetically engineered milk proteins used in drug research, and it says it plans to use the patent to further that production and related research to clone more cattle. The patent is broad enough to include the cloning of human cells -- perhaps the most controversial aspect of bio-technology. Patents. [C13.]

The Bells' Long-Distance Play BellAtlantic is the first local phone giant to take advantage of a change in rules by the Federal Communication Commission that allows local carriers to offer long-distance service. BellAtlantic has already signed up one million long-distance customers in New York, and will try to expand its efforts to other states. Other local providers, like BellSouth and SBC Communications, may follow suit. New Economy. [C4.]

The AP Puts an Emphasis on Maps If the Associated Press succeeds with its newest project, people who read newspapers, watch television news broadcasts or scan Web media sites will have greater access to all kinds of maps. The new product, called MapShop, is a Web-based program designed to allow journalists to create in minutes sophisticated, information-rich maps that once might have taken hours or even days. [C11.]
